comments.commentBody: I almost hope they do. It would make the 2018 midterm election a lot of fun.

Not necessarily, unfortunately. If they do succeed in cutting SS, and Medicare for that matter, by 2018, the damage will be done, and as long as Trump is actually behind the cuts, even with both houses of Congress moving to the Democrats (highly unlikely), any recovery of SS and Medicare will remain a dream no earlier than 2020.
Running for public office is really bad for your mental health.

The idea hinted in the editorial that Trump has any principle or instinct that would lead him to protect benefits for people who are not himself or his ultra-wealthy class is not worthy of consideration.  No, Trump has none such and he will act accordingly.  (Test my prediction at the end of 2017 or even sooner; it seems the Republicans are champing at the bit to loot the government and the country fro their backers.)

The truth is that only one side of the ledger wa s revealed. Had the Republican side been revealed, the American people might have been able to assess which party was more anti-democratic.

An incomplete truth is not truth at all.

Seriously, when has a Presidential candidate been fact-constrained?

I'm not sure Paul Krugman has paid attention to the facts of the election. Many Trump voters voted for Obama in 2008 and 2012. Why the shift? Other Obama voters simply didn't vote. Why? Trump's victory came from close elections in essential swing states; Clinton won the popular vote by more than 2,000,000. Did computer voting systems with no paper trail effect the outcome? (Did the computers record the correct vote? How would one check?)

What about the difference between Candidate Obama and President Obama? Candidate Obama promised transparency. President Obama demonstrated serious opaqueness, attacking whistle-blowers more than anyone.

Six or so years ago, there were no "shovel-ready projects" for infrastructure repair. How did President Obama rectify that claim in the meantime?

Finally, Krugman seems to have blinders on with Clinton's own serious corruption -- as well as her militarism. She supported "humanitarian bombing". Honduras's military takeover wasn't, while Venezuela posed a serious western-hemispheric security risk. Clinton gave speeches for millions of dollars to Goldman and other too-big-to-fail banks. How many of their high officials got prosecuted -- even for large-scale drug-money laundering?

What was Clinton's real position on TPP? What did Clinton tell us about its contents? Who knows what is in TPP?

The time is over to spread conspiracy theories about Clinton. You can look at the provisional texts for TTIP, the US-EU trade agreement that will probably fail ( http://trade.ec.europa.eu/doclib/press/index.cfm?id=1230 ), to get an idea.
It's interesting how every time Prof. Krugman has even mentioned TPP has been to tell us he'll have to get up to speed on it, at some later time. See no evil...

Larry Sabato (Crystal ball) recently put analysis out that showed high visibility in the last phase of the elections to be detrimental and in that sense at least he states it probably has hurt Clinton.
Very clever. Thanks!

Repeal government and replace it with business, more closely defines the mission.

Think of it as privatizing the entire government, and delegating the governance of "we, the people" to the businesses that we work for..........with no real plan for what we do along the way as robots slowly replace the need for human labor. No job (whatever the reason) = no life. Government itself becomes focused on providing services for corporations (first and foremost, defense, intelligence, and policing/enforcement of humans). Those services, of course, would be outsourced to other corporations

It's nothing personal, it's only business.........and, progressive would say: that's the problem!

An ignorant bomb thrower picks other ignorant bomb throwers, as Trump's colossal unfitness for the job begins to metastasize into America's political cancer. And the Republican Party finally realizes its dream of destroying our government and our nation.

Outsiders is a misnomer. It is greed and rich privilege in overdrive.
And it's not what he promised his fans. We can make predictions.
Red states that voted him in will feel the most pain.

Rural workers will suffer the most under the Trump administration.
No living wage, no assistance for college, the jobs aren't coming back.

Trump's merchandise will still be made overseas. He sees no contradiction.
Ivanka Trump moved her out-sourcing to Ethiopia, where workers will earn pennies. Carrier Corporation is still moving to Mexico.

Corporations will max in power + Wall Street + bankers will run wild like predatory animals throughout America and the globe.
Air, water, drug and food safety will be an old dream we used to have.
Public schools to be poorly funded as tax payer money transfers elsewhere and upward to the 1% in unaccountable charter schools.

There will be no providing for the general welfare. Every cent will go the the Defense Department, where companies just like Halliburton/KBR will loot our US Treasury. As they did in the Bush Administration.

Signed, Debbie Downer: (There will be many Debbie Downers)

"Public schools will be poorly finded."  Yeah, keep throwing other people's money into the teacher union dominated cesspools, while the kids education suffers.  Washington, DC spends more $ per pupil than any other school system in the country and its track record on student perfirmance us abysmal.  Michelle Wie tried to do something about it, and was fired for her efforts.  This is the kind if thing Teump was elected to put a stop to.  Stop wasting other people's money - the taxpayers -actual workers who accomplish something every day, and do not live off the government teat.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody: It is wonderful just knowing the knee-jerk reaction the name Halliburton prompts in you.

In one breath the media tells us Trump is packing his cabinet with establishment billionaires. In the next, the same reporters tell us the Washington establishment is trembling.

Which is it?
Some US billionaires are as nutty as fruitcakes. Those are Trump's billionaires.

The red state voters who chose him will suffer the worst of all.
I dread when they all figure that out.

One has to be more precise in looking at the voting process within states. I live in Oregon that solidly went for Clinton, but geographically, it's only 1/4 of the state that voted Democrat. Of course, this section is comparatively more urban, educated, and prosperous. The rural/urban dichotomy is also true for California and Washington as well.

I live in rural Oregon and I absolutely agree with the analysis that it is those who are most dependent on federal care either through social security, Medicare, disability, food stamps, etc. who are also the ones who shake their fists and demand less government. It baffles me; the self-righteous attitude for "self-determination" but demanding their "right" as benefactors of government programs.

In short, the county that I reside in would dry up if it wasn't for the federal government. I see that but you're not going to get the vast majority of the unemployed, elderly, and disabled to recognize it.
The Trump-voting government beneficiary has convinced himself that he's entitled, or earned those benefits. Those People on welfare and illegals getting handouts are another story.

I had been thinking exactly the same thing until it struck me that Donald and his team offer a solution. In order to compete with China, Russia and India the average semi skilled and unskilled American worker must earn 10-12K a year.
I looked at the Trump Cabinet and said eureka 5-6 dollars an hour.
Why is everyone in such a tizzy when only Donald will do what must be done? Who else but Donald and his team can transform the USA into India without a massive insurrection?
If you are like me sit back and enjoy the fact that your grandkids all went to college and university and all speak at least three languages. That is what any middle class Indian would do.

"I don’t think any kind of economic analysis can explain this" is pretty inane when one considers that globalization is largely about moving goods-producing work that require semi-skilled or even skilled blue collar labor to countries where labor is cheap.  That necessarily leads to structural unemployment if no mitigating action is taken.  Krugman himself pointed out in his "Notes on the macroeconomic situation" that we were at nearly full employment with low labor force participation--a good indicator that some have found themselves unemployable.  In another response, Schrodinger points out that a quick perusal of state employment data bears this out.  The industrial revolution did not eliminate agriculture, although agricultural jobs continue to decline; the computer revolution will not eliminate industry, although it does bring automation.  Eventually cheap labor will be replaced by automation, and other jobs will be created to take advantage of the resulting industrial capabilities.  Why is the US not leading the way?  Outsourcing manufacturing gives away that job creation capability.

and Elke
This was barrels OF FUN.
Since I (RE)PRINT the puzzle from AcrossLite and use a pen to fill the grid, I sure wish there had been a warning to use a pencil.... Had to write OVER a significant number- e.g. AVA, became MIA and finally again AVA, and SHOO/SHAG and then SHOO again. RUM/gum because my hand-me-downs could be ageWORN or areWORN....
Hope everybody got this NISSAN correct- just had the NISSAN/NISAN discussion.
ELUL is never "ellul".
Finally I hope the resident EMU becomes an ITINERANT and takes a hike up EL MISTI and sets up its TIPI there.
Good that it is only a RADICLE, and not a "radical", crossing the OVAL OFFICE . But I see danger (75A) in the ROSEGARDEN.
This is an awesome construction and
This was barrels OF FUN.
I tried FISH for something you can do with flies.  No soap in either locale.

Rita:

Sure, his involvement with Breitbart has a LOT to do with the left's distrust of him; but even more is this need to condemn everything ABOUT Trump, even his "known associates". Bannon's methods at Breitbart were HIGHLY transactional and convenient to a general bomb-throwing approach. But, I'm beginning to think like a lot of liberals that right now we NEED a little bomb-throwing, only not of the kind THEY mean.
Hillary's problem wasn't the fake news, it was the real news.
Next, it will be evil space aliens from Venus.

"Fake news has been around since Murdoch formed Fox"

Fake news has been around much longer than that. In other contexts it's known as lying.

But satire affirms the truth, Frank. It doesn't obscure it or try to fool people. The Daily Show has nothing to do with fake news as we're talking about it today. That's like saying the Onion is fake news. It's not, and that the right pretends it is shows that they peddle in obfuscation and deliberate misinformation.

GMooG,

Valid points. But keep in mind that Hillary Clinton won't be in a position to get us into another Middle East war. John Bolton might be.

There is a simple solution to this: Education. Education. Education.

The "left', does not exist in the USA and most people there are so indoctrinated they mistake the 'liberal" centre for the 'left'. The liberal centre, by pandering too much to the right - and the Clinton candidacy was a classic example of this - has allowed these fundamentals to slip, along with far too much more.

Let the interests of the people slip and you will lose them to the proponents of bread and circuses. That's been known for over two thousand years. You reap what you sow.
Actually true leftists do exist in America. The problem has always been that we are very few in number....

Of course. This is why we should have an IQ test for voting. Because everyone who is smart agrees with you.
That's the thinking that lost the election for Hillary

Its time to publicly recognize the real culprits in this mess - the tech companies making billions and billions after having unleashed the free-wheeling, anything-goes online products called "social media" and the everybody-must-have devices called Iphones/cell-phones.

This world wide environment is the perfect hothouse for anyone to say anything to or about anyone and have no consequences whatsoever as long as they pay their cell bill! Lies about nations to turn elections, vicious brutality to destroy the vulnerable, extreme pornography to feed the worst in humanity - you name it you can now have it where ever you are whenever you want

The 21st century is the device/technology happy era of the cowards, the warped and the lazy.

Maybe nature is giving the earth climate change to wipe out the mistake of letting humanity advance into the mire of its own creation.

@Fellow Concerned Citizen: you will NOT flout Federal law when it comes to ILLEGAL ALIEN CRIMINALS, who will be deported along with their illegal families.

Unless you think that California doesn't need any government funds for welfare programs, MediCal, SS, SSDI or Medicare....

Oh, and when the South refused to desegregate, we sent in troops. We will send them to San Francisco, too.

You will NOT defy the Federal Government on this issue and get away with it.

This sort of thing used to be called dirty tricks. Yes, it was unethical, no, it was not illegal and no one ever took it all that seriously. If you followed US politics you expected to find it and if it made your candidate look bad it was easy to just ignore it. What we are seeing now isnt much different, only the paranoia has been raised to a truly alarming level. What makes this situation different, is that the dirty trick in question distorted nothing and propagated nothing that wasnt actually the case. I see it as a very minor and relatively innocuous version of the Pentagon Papers -- or the revelations of Snowden. Whats suspicious is not the so-called hacking, but the extraordinary effort on the part of Democrats to use this as a policy tool, almost as though it was another Gulf of Tonkin incident. If any group is trying to influence US politics its the folks behind this brouhaha, not the Russians. And yes, it is VERY alarming.

"This sort of thing used to be called dirty tricks. Yes, it was unethical, no, it was not illegal and no one ever took it all that seriously."

What garbage !There is a nice job for you in a Fake News Boiler room.
Are you here to try and neutralize the article?

This is not minor, I'm afraid. The Pentagon Papers, Watergate, etc., were domestic. This is international. I'm torn between being all for free speech and putting a wall up where international political meddling is concerned. (And yes, I know the US has done it too,) I just hope the electoral college grows a spine on Monday and that at least 38 "faithless electors" figure out that being faithful to the intent of the constitution and the design of their institution is more important than party, and that they vote their consciences and not allow Donald Trump to hold an office that he lost by 2.8 million votes.
